Metadata: Quantification of stress in lobsters: crustacean hyperglycemic hormone, stress proteins, and gene expression

Decades ago researchers discovered that injected eyestalk extracts were able to elevate the blood glucose in crabs. The hormone responsible for this hyperglycemic effect has in the last 8 years been identified, and is commonly referred to as the crustacean hyperglycemic hormone (CHH). This paper reports the development of a sensitive ELISA for CHH, the use of the ELISA as a tool for the quantification of environmental stresses in lobsters, the characterizatioâ€‹n of a probe for the CHH gene(s), and its use in northern blot analyses.
